verses.text: Do not be jealous over the wife of your heart, and do not teach her an evil lesson against yourself.
verses.comment: The verse warns husbands not to be suspicious and harsh, linking jealousy to destructive behavior. Cross reference with Proverbs about faithfulness and wisdom in marital relationships.

verses.text: Do not give your soul to a woman so that she has power over your strength.
verses.comment: Alluding to Samson and Delilah (Judg. 16), this warns against uncontrolled passions, paralleling the wisdom tradition that calls for self-mastery.

verses.text: Do not meet with a harlot, lest you fall into her snares.
verses.comment: Like Proverbs, this is a warning against sexual immorality and its consequences, emphasizing the importance of fleeing temptation.

verses.text: Do not keep company with a singing girl, lest you be caught by her tricks.
verses.comment: The text warns of those who use charm or entertainment for seduction—a broader caution about where and how we seek pleasure.

verses.text: Do not stare at a virgin, lest you stumble and bring guilt upon yourself.
verses.comment: Anticipates Jesus’ teaching on lust (Matt. 5:28). Not merely outward actions but also the inward gaze is to be pure.

verses.text: Do not give yourself to prostitutes, lest you lose your inheritance.
verses.comment: Retains the original text's emphasis that sexual sin can have lasting spiritual and material consequences.

verses.text: Do not look around in the streets of the city, or wander in its deserted places.
verses.comment: Avoiding places of temptation is consistent with wisdom literature’s call for prudence in avoiding the near occasions of sin.

verses.text: Turn your eyes away from a beautiful woman, and do not gaze upon another’s beauty; for many have been destroyed because of a woman, and through this passion, fire is kindled.
verses.comment: Captures the theme of caution regarding lustful desires; parallels Jesus’ deepening of the Law in the Sermon on the Mount.

verses.text: Do not sit at table with another man’s wife, or join her in drinking wine, lest your soul turn to her and you slide into destruction in your heart.
verses.comment: A warning against both appearance and proximity to occasions of sin—spiritual wisdom also underlies Church tradition on boundaries.

verses.text: Do not abandon an old friend, for a new one cannot take his place. A new friend is like new wine; when it has aged, you will drink it with pleasure.
verses.comment: Values loyalty and long-term relationships, pointing to the Church’s emphasis on tradition and continuity in spiritual friendships.

verses.text: Do not envy the success of a sinner, for you do not know how his life will end.
verses.comment: Similar to the Psalms, this underlines the fleeting nature of worldly prosperity without righteousness.

verses.text: Do not rejoice at the death of anyone; remember that we all must die.
verses.comment: Promotes humility and reverence for life, echoing New Testament teaching on mercy and universal mortality.

verses.text: Do not neglect the discourse of the wise; remain in their company as long as you live.
verses.comment: This verse highlights respect for spiritual authority and tradition, affirming the need for oral and lived wisdom within the believing community.

verses.text: Love to listen to every godly discourse, but do not let the sayings of the foolish escape you.
verses.comment: Balances openness to truth with discernment, encouraging the faithful to treasure sound doctrine.

verses.text: Speak with wise people, and all your conversation should be on the Law of the Most High.
verses.comment: Elevates the Law and conversation rooted in it, supporting the relationship of tradition and scripture in shaping moral life.

verses.text: Associate with righteous people, and let your life always be with those who you know keep the commandments.
verses.comment: Faithful companionship strengthens virtue and perseverance, a key spiritual principle for building up the community.

verses.text: Let your heart consider the fear of the Lord, and always seek counsel from wise people.
verses.comment: Echoes the wisdom tradition: fearing God is the beginning of wisdom and the believer should continually seek spiritual direction.

verses.text: Wisdom is praised more than eloquence, and one who is understanding will gain favor in the Lord’s sight.
verses.comment: Prioritizes virtue over mere words, aligning with Christ’s teaching that wisdom and understanding produce authentic favor before God.
